newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy ponders incentives to boost building sector.
newsitem.headline: Italy ponders incentives to boost building sector.

text.p: The Italian government, flushed with the success of its recent initiatives to boost car sales, is considering introducing incentives to encourage the country's depressed building sector.
Finance Minister Vincenzo Visco and Industry Minister Pierluigi Bersani were both quoted as saying on Sunday that the government planned to intervene to help the sector.
"The incentives won't be extravagent but they will be important," Visco said.

Newspapers said any incentive schemes would be included in the 1998 budget, which has to be unveiled by the end of September 1997. Among measures being studied are a reduction in value added tax on building work.
The building sector was badly hit by the wave of corruption scandals which washed over Italy in the early 1990s.
Many public work projects ground to a halt or were simply cancelled as magistrates investigated claims that construction firms paid politicians huge kickbacks to win contracts.
Constructors association Ance has asked the government to cut taxes on building work and on people buying first houses in a bid to kick start the flagging industry.
Italy's centre-left government introduced incentives at the start of the year to encourage people to scrap their old cars and buy new ones.
The scheme has led to a huge jump in car sales, with analysts estimating that the Treasury has actually made some 600 billion lire ($353 million) because of the increased sales.
